newsitem.title: USA: Vermont Yankee will close if deregulation passes.
newsitem.headline: Vermont Yankee will close if deregulation passes.

text.p: A spokesman for Vermont's largest electric utility Central Vermont Public Service Corp said Friday that the state's only nuclear plant will be shutdown if a provision passed by a state Senate committee becomes law.

The Vermont Senate Natural Resources Committee passed a utility restructuring containing a financial incentive for the nuclear plant to shut down in five years. If the plant remains open longer, the utility will be liable for any additional maintenance and de-commissioning costs.

Charles Satterlee, a spokesman for CVPS which with Green Mountain Power co-owns the Vermont Yankee nuclear plant in Vernon, said that "even though on the face of it it's a fair provision, we couldn't afford to take the risk. We'd opt for the closure of the plant.
"Most other companies in New England are much larger and if there is a bad year, they can write it off," he said. "Vermont utilities can't stand that bad year."

After the vote, committee chairwoman Elizabeth Ready, a Democrat from Addison County, called the provision "a once in a lifetime chance to make this kind of progress for the environment and for consumers.
The bill mandates that 15 percent of the power purchases be from renewalable sources.
The measure now goes to the full Senate. If it passes, it moves on to the House of Representatives. If the measure survives both votes, Gov. Howard Dean is likely to sign it into law.
